title: Are smartphone cameras getting better than DSLRs? - Quora

response.answer_text: For most casual users, a smartphone will produce a better result in most circumstances than a digital Single Lens Reflex (dSLR) camera. The reason is that, despite the much poorer optics and dramatically smaller sensor size, the artificial intelligence built into the smart phone ‘knows’ much more than most users do, and is able to make all kinds of adjustments that a really good photographer would make when shooting with a high-end dSLR. Entry-level dSLRs have a number of automatic modes, such as ‘portrait’, ‘landscape’, and so on, which do this to some extent, but the electronics in smartphones are much more powerful—the smartphone is, essentially, a computer which can apply all of its processing power to the task of taking a picture. For 70% of photographs, that’s all you need. Now, consider this image. I’m not suggesting this is a particularly good image, but it demonstrates a couple of things that a smartphone can’t do.  First off, this is shot with a 500mm lens, manually focussed, at 1/4000. You can count the hairs, and you can also see the droplets of water frozen in time. It looks close, but it was actually out in the middle of a pond. Second, at 500mm, the depth of field is about 1 cm. Autofocus can’t keep track of that on a smartphone. This is a momentary shot. On a high-end dSLR, you click the shutter and the photo is captured. On a smartphone, there is a lag. You aren’t getting the shot you want. Third, this is shot with manual focus. You can’t manually focus on a smartphone. Fourth, at 1/3200 on f8, you need a lot of gain. This shot is at ISO 50000. The iPhone XS Max only goes as far as 6400. Now, admittedly, the Huwai P30 Pro has been announced as going up to 409600 — twice the maximum ISO of the camera used to capture this. But, wait, it’s always possible to increase the apparent ISO. In post-processing, the image shown can be taken up to an effective ISO of more than 1 million. The Huwai P30 Pro is clearly a triumph of engineering and software, but it still can’t take a 500mm lens. See next point. And, that’s a current camera versus a seven-year old camera (see last point). The Nikon D6 goes up to 3,280,000 ISO — eight times as much as the Huwai P30 Pro. Fifth, a dSLR is a system camera. The lens in question, a 500mm, was designed in the 1960s, and this particular example was probably from the 1970s. It still works on current Nikon cameras. In a few seconds, that lens can be swapped for a fisheye lens with a 180° angle of view, corner to corner. Or it can be swapped again for an 85mm tilt-shift lens. It can control a studio light setup, potentially up to hundreds of lights, and it can control a set of Speedlights (portable flash) positioned in various places. Sixth, all of the controls are available to the photographer on a dSLR. If you want to drag the shutter, use rear-synchronisation, so that the flash fires at the end of the shot rather than the beginning, choose speed or aperture priority, or shoot fully manually, or take a shot of up to 30 seconds, you can. The Huwai P30 Pro can shoot in low light, but it can’t shoot extended exposures. Seventh, you can charge up a dSLR and shoot on it intensively for a week. A smartphone will be dead in a matter of hours. Battery empty? Swap it out for the other one in your pocket. Finally, the camera used for this is a 2013 camera, a Nikon Df. My other camera is from 2012. The Df is still available. It can shoot with lenses built in the 1950s. Its all metal construction means that if you drop it, things that it falls onto break. The camera doesn’t. You can still get a Nikon D1 repaired—that’s the first commercially viable dSLR, from 1999, replacing the marginally workable Kodak hybrid camera.  Smartphones are much better at being phones than dSLRs, but they are nowhere near being able to do the work of a dSLR in the hands of a proper photographer.  Here’s an image shot this week with a Nikon Df and a 500mm lens:  Here’s a crop of it:  Here are some things that the smartphone can’t do: Interchangeable lenses. There will never be a smartphone with a 500mm lens. It is physically impossible.Ultra high ISO. To shoot at 1/4000, which is how you get 500mm lens shots sharp when cropping, you need to go to insanely high ISO.Ring bokeh. A mirror lens produces a distinctive doughnut shaped bokeh. Smartphones don’t produce a particularly good bokeh anyway, but the particular delight of the mirror lens cannot be achieved on a smartphone.If ring bokeh isn’t your thing, a smartphone also can’t do tilt/shift photography or selective defocus, or take a polarising filter.Ergonomically, you could never shoot a sharp image on a lens of that length with a smartphone even if a smartphone could be equipped with such a lens. You need a body which is designed to be good for taking photographs, not for slipping into your back pocket.

No, they are simply more idiot-proof. A person with no idea about photography will get better results with a smartphone than with a DSLR because in the case of a smartphone all they have to do is press the button. The software behind the camera is designed to do all the thinking for them (pumping up the ISO and removing noise afterwards in the case of night shots for example to not allow for excessive motion blur). Auto mode usually works quite poorly in DSLRs because they aren’t really meant to be used in auto mode. Also, the quality of JPGs produced by DSLRs often leaves a lot to be desired. Again, ideally one would be shooting RAW when using a DSLR. Smartphones don’t feature magic sensors and magic lenses that are somehow better than the DSLR ones that cost big bucks. A tiny sensor and a tiny lens will always be inferior to their larger counterparts (when comparing recent products at the same stage of sensor technology development). No, I’m not talking about megapixels. Unlike what’s been said in this thread, Nokia 808 doesn’t have a larger sensor than a DSLR. Its sensor is about 11x8mm (that’s quite sizeable for a smartphone actually, the sensor of iPhone 6 is a mere 4.89x3.67mm). A typical crop DSLR’s sensor is about 24x16mm. Full frame is 36x24mm. The Nokia does have a larger resolution than most DSLRs but that’s a different matter. Don’t get fooled by smartphone fanboys/girls saying DSLRs are becoming obsolete because “look what a cute photo of my cat my iPhone took!!!”. If they were as obsessed about photography as they are about having access to Facebook wherever they go then they wouldn’t mind the extra bulk carrying a camera around. If you want to go beyond pressing a button and applying a filter then you need a camera that will give you control over the picture and will provide you with quality output that you can then process to your liking. Doesn’t need to be a DSLR. Doesn’t need to be much more expensive than a smartphone either.

Yikes! Is it time for the monthly phone vs. DSLR question already? How time does fly…  Here’s the Nikon D1. This is a 2.7 megapixel DSLR that Nikon introduced in 1999. It was original sold at $5,580, which is about $8,450 today. If you want to feel superior with your smartphone, rest assured that your premium phone today takes an over-all better photo than this 19-year-old DSLR. Unless, of course, you need to shoot a distant object — the D1 can adapt by using a longer lens. Or unless you need to shoot a very, very close object — the D1 can adapt by using a true macro lens. Of if you need to shoot a really pleasing portrait with a naturally out-of-focus background. Some phones have secondary cameras with longer lenses, though not really ideal portrait length, and software to fake it. The D1 still does it better. And at 12-bits per color, the D1 probably has better color than your phone. But maybe surprisingly, even with an APS-C sized sensor, the D1 wasn’t much good in low light. It had an ISO around 100–200, while your phone can certainly shoot much, much faster, maybe to ISO3200–6400, though it’s going be kind of a noisy mess there. Contrast that with Nikon’s current high-end pro model, the D5, which has an ISO limit of 3,280,000. Yeah, it’s kind of a noisy mess, too, at ISO3,280,000. But at ISO6400, the Nikon D5 is pretty much just getting started. I’m not sure how fast anyone can actually shoot photos on a phone… “not all that fast” seems to be my experience. The D1 can shoot at 4.5 frames per second, which isn’t all that fast in DSLR land, but should soundly beat your phone. But it only had buffer memory for 10 shots in raw mode. It also had very fast autofocus, but that is more important on a large sensor camera than the tiny sensors used in phones, which have all kinds of natural depth-of-field. But the typical 12 megapixels of your phone will deliver a better over-all photo as long as both cameras have good light. At least if you plan to make a print. Online, however, it just doesn’t matter in most cases. The average computer user has an HD computer display, only about 2 megapixels, so you can’t actually see the difference between your phone shot and the D1’s lower resolution shot without zooming in. If you have a 4K monitor, you can — assuming the image is stored at a higher resolution online. If you’re looking at Instagram, no dice: it stores and displays everything at 1080x1080 pixels. On Facebook, your photo may be stored at a higher resolution, but it’s displayed at 476 pixels wide, no matter the actual resolution. So you can’t tell here, either. Now, that D1 will have access to dramatically better lenses than anything anyone ever put on a phone. Thing is, at 2.7 megapixels, you aren’t going to noice. If you hang one of those lenses on today’s Nikon D850, with its 45 megapixel full-frame sensor, you’ll get the advantage of Nikon’s 60 years of wonderful optics. In short, yes, at the dawn of digital, every camera was something of a compromise, because humanity was just not all that good at making digital cameras yet. The quality from model to model increased pretty dramatically for years. The followup to the D1, Nikon’s D1X in 2001, increased sensor resolution to 5.3 megapixels, nearly doubling it. And of course, if you go back much before 2011, smartphone cameras were just terrible. Manufacturers only really started thinking about such cameras as practical alternatives for point and shoot/compact digital cameras around 2010–2011. Prior to that, they were there primarily for utility value: scanning barcodes, shooting “memo” photos, video conferencing, etc. But if you’re comparing contemporary professional cameras to contemporary smartphone cameras, just stop. There phone camera will never compare well in quality to the professional camera in image quality. The much larger sensor of the DSLR or mirrorless camera will capture more resolution, both spatial and color. You may not take advantage of this is you treat your DSLR like a point-and-shoot, just shooting in JPEG through a kit lens and publishing straight-out-of-camera. But if you’re using it correctly, shooting in raw and editing each acceptable photo to take advantage of all of the extra information you get in a raw image before publishing, you’ll be making images that no smartphone can touch… technically. Of course, as Ansel Adams said, “The single most important component of a camera is the twelve inches behind it!” While maybe the smartphone AI people are trying to change this, the creativity is yours, not your camera’s. If you develop talents in photography, you’ll get great shots with a phone camera. If you don’t know what you’re doing, a high-end DSLR is not going to help you. Yet. No. For some background, see Jeff Forbes's answer to How much more can smartphone cameras improve? The limitation of a camera system is from the optics and sensor - how much light they can collect, and how much detail they can resolve. If you read my answer above, you will see how far cellphone cameras have advanced since the early days of the smartphone. The very short version of it is that smartphone sensors are 5 times as large as they used to be, the lenses are larger and better, and more effort is being put in to developing them. But as car guys say, there’s no replacement for displacement. In this case, smartphones are held to the same limitations as everything else - DSLRs and mirrorless cameras have sensors many times as large, with much more capable lenses attached to them. Smartphones have come a long way. These days, there can be situations that for small display sizes, such as a laptop screen or cellphone screen, there may not be a huge difference in image quality. This is limited to situations where the cellphone and SLR are using a similar equivalent focal length lens for the same perspective, a lot of light being present, and the way the picture is being displayed is a small screen. In these cases, a cellphone picture can look just as good as one from an SLR. But if there’s less light, or you need to control the depth of field, or if you need more detail for a very large print, or heavily process the image, the difference will be far more apparent. Modern smartphones are now often as good as nice point and shoot cameras, and oftentimes better than them. But they are still at a disadvantage compared to an SLR. One area of note that may make cellphone pictures look better is that SLRs don’t heavily post-process their images automatically. If you look at a RAW capture from an SLR. it will often look quite dull and flat. This is because the camera is simply presenting the scene as captured without significantly modifying it. Pretty much every cellphone on the market takes the base image and sharpens it, performs noise reduction on it, adjusts the color and contrast, and oftentimes automatically makes an HDR image. So comparing a cellphone picture to a RAW file directly from an SLR is rather disingenuous. One is an automatically processed image and the other is intended to be processed by the user.

Yes. But it depends what you are using it for. Many pros demand quality images, for this they ante up on a expensive DSLR camera to do the job. However, if you have no need to get top notch picture quality, why use a DSLR? During my time at Sony Asia Pacific 10 years ago, they told me explicitly that the rise of camera phones will eventually replace the entry level DSLR. And they didn’t want to even make point and shoot digital cameras below 8 megapixels at that time. What they wanted to engineer was a higher quality DSLR product, which according to Michael Yamashita of Natgeo (who I had the pleasure to work with) would eventually make photography a gentleman’s hobby. The advances in light sensitive sensors on camera phones have been extraordinary in the last 10 years. From the first generation iPhone to the newest iPhone X or Google Pixel, camera phones have evolved to replace the market segment for entry level DSLRs. I have also seen the marketshare for DSLRs decline sharply. This is nothing short of astonishing considering that it was only in the mid-2000s that mobile phones started to pack cameras. Right now, the trend is for cameras to do both still and video capture, and for this alone the smartphone is already better at doing it at far less than it cost to buy a entry level DSLR. High end DSLRs are stupidly expensive to buy these days and unless you have a booming photography business going for you, buying one for hobby use is without any justification. The demand for paid photos have also declined. In the old days, digital stock photos could only be purchased from folks like Corel who sold them on a CD. The advent of the Internet sort of changed everything. You can now buy online for as little as 1 dollar or have a monthly paid subscription to access thousands of photos. I started shooting on film back in the day, so I know this well. I use to admire conflict photographers in the analog era, and even met Eddie Adams. They made a good living shooting film and were handsomely paid. You can’t say the same these days with digital photos. But the technology of DSLRs has far exceeded what film SLRs could do. There is no need to attach filters for WB controls and you can dial in the ISO speed anytime you wish (a feat that film SLRs could not do). The race now is to make a better DSLR that is cheaper. Unfortunately camera companies are not interested in the mass market because that segment competes directly with smartphone cameras. They prefer to concentrate on niche markets that people still buy cameras for, like in Sports, Commercial photography, Wedding, etc. This is the only paying segment of the photography market that makes sense for people to own a DSLR. Pros like to talk about the picture quality of DSLRs but if they ever showed a client a picture shot in daylight on an iPhone X and one that is shot on a DSLR, the difference is hard to distinguish. And smartphones like the Huawei, is fast catching up on low light capability—a domain where DSLRs excel at the moment. It will only be a matter of time before technology makes it viable to replace the DSLR.

Absolutely, totally and completely, no. This can never happen. Could a simple fireworks rocket take you to the moon and back again? Just basic sense should tell you the answer. A typical smartphone costs, say, $700. In that smartphone you've bought a multipurpose device containing more computing power than desktop computers had some years ago. It contains a powerful UHF radio transceiver for digitally-secure speech and SMS messages and dozens of apps you might want to install. In other words it's a combined pocket computer with a comms centre. AND on top if that, they toss in two cameras, on average. One rear, one front. Economics should already be telling you where this is going… When a phone gives you all those things in one combined package, is it sensible to expect those cameras to approach what a DSLR can provide? No, it's not. HOWEVER. Those cameras are, in my experience now so good that they do approach the sort of image quality obtainable from compact cameras. And some allow the recording of RAW files, which record far, far more data than do the JPG compressed equivalent. And the video quality that my Samsung S8 gives is astonishing. In that regard only, my phone is a more effective one than my DSLR cameras. But my DSLRs are all outdated models these days, and only record video up to Full HD, or 1080p whereas my S8 can do video up to full on 4K… So can the current breed of DSLRs. Where the DSLRs will still score however is in the fantastic quality of their lenses. And in their ability to shoot in low light, because they are dedicated photography specialist machines. Your smartphone for still pictures can't compete with decent DSLRs, economics dictates that the specialist machine must defeat the tiny-sensor generalist camera in the phone. But having said that, smartphones nowadays are taking shots that only a few years ago would have needed a good quality camera. But you can change the lens on a DSLR, that's not "on" with a phone. Where the phone will always beat the DSLR, however, is that you most likely always have it with you. Do you always have a DSLR in your pocket??? That's where the phone camera wins. The best camera is - the one you have with you. And that'll almost always be a smartphone-cam, with all its shortcomings. They are two completely different beasts, and both are valuable tools for the picshooter. A huge majority of my shots these days are phone pix, but if I want a quality landscape for fine detail or a flying bird, it's the DSLRs every time.

No. There may be situations where they are easier to use or to get good results, but the limitations of camera phones are here to stay. First, the sheer adaptability of an SLR knocks any phone into a cocked hat. If you want to change the field of view on your phone, you can move or you can crop your image. Even a basic kit lens gives you infinitely more options than that. And when you can swap lenses out, you are not bound to a single perspective but can select the exact tool for the job, with the precise focal length you require. Next, there is the size of the sensor. However many teeny tiny pixels you can fit behind the teeny tiny lens on your phone, they are never going to keep up with an APSC or Full Frame sensor, especially in low light. Bigger, more accurate pixels make cleaner, sharper and more realistic pictures. And last, but not least, there's the glass. Now camera makers are very proud of the quality of their lenses, and rightly so, they are excellent at what they do. But that doesn't mean they can seriously match up to the top range glass you'll find on an SLR. Look how much a good superzoom costs. You could buy a lifetime supply of phones for the price of a top end lens. People don't pay that sort of money for nothing. They are paying for image quality that you simply cannot get any cheaper. And that's without going into things like selective autofocus, dials for manual control of shutter speed and aperture, high fps, continuous capture and all the other things a real camera can do. There's no substitute for a good camera. But. That said… You can make the exact same comparison between DSLR cameras and Medium Format cameras and the DSLR comes off second best there. The best camera is the one in your hand. The greatest limits to a modern photographer are not technical but come from not learning, understanding and developing the skills to construct a great image. Pictures I take with my phone now are often better photographs than my first attempts with a DSLR were. Not because the tech is better, but because I am. Go and take photos with whatever you have access to.

The simple answer is No. Why? Because there are a lot of factors that are necessary to be considered when talking about this topic, and here are few factors that might help you out. 1.Image Sensor Size There are different sensors used in different cameras. When there are different sensors that also includes different sizes of sensors. A basic DSLR can have a crop sensor or APS-c sensor and it sizes about 23.6 x 14 mm (the size again will vary with different manufacturers). And to hold this size of sensor the smartphones has to be made bigger. Relatively there are other bigger sensors such as Full frame and it sizes about 35 X 24 mm, which is almost twice the size of the APS-C sensor. There is a Medium Format sensor and it sizes about 53 x 40 mm. It is really hard for the smartphone manufactures to build a phone to hold a sensor of this size. As the sensor size increases the light captured by the sensor is more and does a good job in low light situations.  2. The Blur (Bokeh) The smartphones actually use software to manipulate the background blurs in the image. Even the software is not so perfect to bring the blur that is produced optically (using the lens only). I tried creating a Bokehlicious image using leading smartphone and the blur is not masked well. Sometimes it cuts out the edges of the subject and gets it blurred too. 3. Interchangeable Lens This is one of the most loved features of a DSLR for all pro shooters. It is always necessary to use right lens for the right type of photography. And DSLR allows you to change lenses based on the requirements. There are almost different variety of lenses for landscape, portrait, wildlife, architecture, low-light and more. 4. Features Though smartphones capture great images, DSLR offers more flexibility over the features listed below. The below list is only a few but DSLRs offer more. - Kelvin Scale White balance adjustment - Metering Modes - Auto Focus Modes - Multiple Exposures - Shutter and Aperture Priority Modes

Yes and no. When I was younger, my first camera was a cheap Kodak Instamatic that shot 126 film. My family had a somewhat better camera that shot 126 film while I was growing up, and we later upgraded to one of the Kodak disk film cameras (we also briefly had a Kodak Trimprint until Polaroid won a lawsuit and Kodak had to stop making film for them). For a few decades, these point-and-shoot one-click cameras were fairly common for casual users. You’d buy a roll of film, usually about 24 shots or so, snap away, then take them to Photo-Mat or somewhere to get them developed. SLR cameras at the time were a bit more complex and not ideal for the average casual user. I bought my first (used) 35mm SLR around 1992 and used it up until the early 2000’s. It didn’t have auto focus, but did have an auto exposure setting for shutter speed along with a built-in light meter. While it wasn’t too difficult to learn, cameras like this required some extra skill to use: you had to consider the aperture, the depth of field, the shutter speed, whether or not to use a flash, etc… For casual use, most people preferred the point-and shoot variety. In the 2000’s, digital cameras started to become the norm. While they had been around for a little while already, they were typically too expensive for the casual and even many serious users. Additionally, personal computer technology wasn’t advanced enough to make them practical for the average user. Software to read the images from the camera memory or import from a card was slow, image rendering was slow, and image manipulation was rudimentary. A lot of people didn’t have a computer at home yet, and most people who had internet access till had dial-up access. As the 2000’s progressed, however, several things came together. Computer speeds increased and the usability of Microsoft Windows and Apple Macintosh OSX increased (though Apple had been pretty easy to use for a while). In the mid 90’s, transferring a 800x600 pixel JPG might have taken several minutes. In the mid 2000’s, higher speed internet access dropped that to seconds. Rendering time went from a minute or two in the early to mid 90’s to seconds. And the cost of digital cameras dropped dramatically with advances in manufacturing and the increasing popularity of CMOS imaging sensors. The advances in on-board processing capability started to narrow the usability gap between point-and-shoot cameras and DSLRs. The price of a DSLR was typically higher, but most DSLR cameras could now be used almost as easily as the less-advanced cousins. This made them a bit more attractive to casual users who could afford them. They tended to offer advanced functions for those who wanted them, but could also be used almost as easy as a point-and-shoot camera. At this point, the main difference for the bulk of consumers was price. And at right about this same time, cell phones started taking off. Sometime in the early to mid 2000’s, cameras became standard features on cell phones. With the advent of smartphones. Suddenly, everyone had a camera in their pocket. As smart phone technology advanced and, along with it, wireless and WiFi internet speeds, the gap between point and shoot cameras and cell phones rapidly decreased. There are still dedicated point and shoot cameras available today, but most smartphones these days can take pictures as good or better - or at least good enough for most average users - than the dedicated point and shoot variety. And the technology and capability of cell phone cameras, which is a major selling point for many phones, has pretty much entirely caught up with point-and-shoot cameras. Some people still prefer them, and some provide some additional features that aren’t practical in cell phones (such as extended optical zoom capabilities), but for the average casual user, their cell phone camera is as good as they need for most casual photography: capturing selfies, images of friends and family, unusual events or occurrences - and they don’t have to carry around a separate device: they have their phone with them anyway. So, as far as casual photography goes, yes, a cell phone can replace a DSLR for most casual users. But DSLR and now mirrorless cameras have features and benefits not yet available (and probably never to be available) in a cell phone. One such difference is image sensor size. The image sensor of a cell phone camera is typically very small, measured in a few millimeters. DSLRs typically have two sensor sizes: full-frame - meaning image sensors roughly the same size as a frame of 35 mm film - and APS-C, which are typically somewhat smaller, but still much larger than cell phone camera sensors. Larger sensors often (though not always) have more pixels, offering deeper resolution, and typically capture more light with a larger surface area (important in some applications such as low-light photography). DSLR cameras also typically offer a significantly greater amount of control over the image capture process. While some cell phone apps do offer some extended features, the amount of control a photographer has over shutter speed, exposure level, aperture control, depth of field, color balance, and more allow a trained user to capture better images. Though at least some cell phone cameras do allow for higher-quality image files, DSLR cameras commonly shoot in a raw, “lossless,” image format. Most cell phones by default save files in JPG image format, which compresses data and, in doing so, loses dynamic range and image quality. While some DSLR users choose to shoot JPG, most who are making use of the extended capability of the camera shoot a raw format and convert as needed. The raw format allows them far more capability when processing in programs like Photoshop. Most cell phones also are stuck with their built-in flash. While this is fine for casual use, an experienced photographer can make use of a DSLR flash unit that provides superior control over lighting, allowing him/her to produce better effects, reduce the effects of “red-eye,” and overall get better lighting of the subject. And, of course, there is the ability to change lenses for different needs. With all of this capability, much of which is not practical to add to a cell phone, It’s unlikely DSLR or the recent development in mirrorless cameras will be replaced outright by cell phones. Rather, cell phones will continue for some time to be the main tool of casual photographers and the more advanced cameras will be the working tools of more serious photographers. Speaking personally, I have two DSLRs (one of which is specially modified for astrophotography) as well as my cell phone. Lately, the DSLRs are only used for astrophotography and everything else is done with my iPhone. However, since my girlfriend and I are considering doing some travelling in the next few years, I may look into a new lens or two and some additions for my DSLR that will give me the ability to capture better images on travel. For example, one of the reasons I bought a film SLR in the first place was to take pictures of objects in museums that may not allow for flash photography. I visited one museum once that had illuminated manuscripts on display, but wouldn’t allow any flash photography as the light could damage the artifacts. At the time, I purchased some higher-speed Kodak Ektar 1000 speed film which allowed me, to make use of the exposure control settings on my camera and capture some images without a flash (sadly, I have no idea where those pictures have gone). If I want to take pictures under similar circumstances now, my iPhone really isn’t the right tool for the job. I’ll get much better results with my Nikon if I play with the exposure settings. But, other than astrophotography, the vast majority of the images I take are now all done on my iPhone which does better than any point-an-shoot camera I’ve ever had to this point.

When you take a picture you actually run into a complex process involving : Creation intentLens picture deformationSensor capturePicture post-processingThe short answer is that in some cases, phone camera can overrun DSLRs, but in most of the case, they can’t. The most obvious case where phones win is in everyday usage as you always have it with you. But if you set this scenario apart, and suppose you have your DSLR , that ‘s another story. If you want to have a special creation intent, such as stopping a bird flight, or on the contrary demonstrate the flow of a river, you’ll have to fiddle with speed parameter, which most of to the cases are not available on the phone camera. If you want to create bokeh (blur around a portrait head) or have perfect sharpness from the first grass a the forefront up to the mountains on the horizon, you’ll have to fiddle with depth of field and aperture parameter, which most of the cases is not available on the phone camera. If you want to crop from afar this vulture nest, you’ll need a big zoom which your phone can’t offer. OK, but you might say , this is only temporary, one day you’ll have all of it on your phone, and they will win. Actually, no. Because the law of physics are here to stay also. Basically , what they say is that you need a big aperture and a big sensor to store enough light information. It’s the optical equivalent of “you need a big woofer to render bass sounds”. Light at the core is quantic. You receive discret number of photons. If you don’t have them, you can’t invent the picture. You can’t set up a magical algorithm to create the data you don’t have. That’s ultimately the advantage of DSLR. When you go away from an easy scenario where you are taking a picture of a still landscape brightly lit by the summer sun, you begin with the phone to be short of photons. Your sensor is so small that you don’t have enough information to tell wether this is light grey or dark grey. You have also random noise, light noise (there were two photons in your shot, while normally 1.5 should have be expected) or electrical noise. So in low lights scenarios, or high speeds for fast moving subjects, phone cameras really are bad, and this can’t really be improved to the level of DSLRs. You can try to raise the number of pixels in the phone - in order to store more details -, but you also need to open the door to have something to store, in other word to raise the aperture (the size of the lens) and then the size of the device, because you need to have a focal plan related with the lens size. The iPhone X is going this direction, by offering two lenses, but this is still a very small step to come closer to the potential of a real DSLR lens. That the reason why professionals still pay a fortune for DSLRs. It’s not pure snobbery.

Modern sensors are so advanced in their technology that you really do run up against physical limits if you want to take a picture in poor light with a reasonably short shutter speed. Modern smartphone cameras are fantastically good: provided the wide angle of view they provide is appropriate, in good light they are pretty much as good as the 35mm cameras most people used in film days.
